sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_1: What is the Ramsey number R(4,4)?
message_2:
The Ramsey number R(m, n) is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size m (a complete subgraph with m vertices) or an independent set of size n (a set of n vertices with no edges between them).

For R(4,4), it is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size 4 or an independent set of size 4.

The exact value of R(4,4) is 18. This means that in any graph with 18 vertices, there must be either a complete subgraph with 4 vertices or an independent set of 4 vertices.
